title: 107_hr1478
content: The "Personal Information Privacy Act of 2001" includes provisions for the confidential treatment of credit header information and prohibits the use of Social Security numbers for commercial purposes without consent. The "Personal Information Privacy Act of 2001" prohibits the commercial acquisition or distribution of Social Security numbers without written consent. It also prohibits the use of Social Security numbers for personal identification without consent. Consent must be obtained by informing individuals of all purposes for which their information will be used. The "Personal Information Privacy Act of 2001" requires obtaining written consent before using Social Security numbers for any purpose, with exceptions for specific legal requirements. Individuals can take civil action in a US district court for violations, seeking relief and damages. The "Personal Information Privacy Act of 2001" allows individuals to seek preliminary relief, actual or liquidated damages, attorney's fees, and costs in civil actions for violations. The statute of limitations for such actions is 3 years. The "Personal Information Privacy Act of 2001" allows individuals to seek relief for violations, with a statute of limitations of 3 years. The remedy provided under this subsection is in addition to any other available remedy. Civil money penalties of up to $25,000 per violation and up to $500,000 for frequent violations may be imposed by the Commissioner of Social Security. The "Personal Information Privacy Act of 2001" allows individuals to seek relief for violations, with civil money penalties of up to $25,000 per violation and up to $500,000 for frequent violations imposed by the Commissioner of Social Security. Violations involving multiple individuals' social security account numbers are treated as separate violations. Enforcement procedures from section 1128A apply to civil money penalties under this subsection. The Commissioner of Social Security is responsible for coordinating enforcement with criminal activities related to fraud and identity theft. States are not prohibited from enacting their own regulations in this regard. The amendment allows states to enact laws for privacy protection. It applies to violations occurring two years after enactment. Refusing business due to lack of consent for social security number is considered unfair or deceptive, leading to action under the Federal Trade Commission Act. SEC. 4. REPEAL OF CERTAIN PROVISIONS RELATING TO DISTRIBUTION OF CONSUMER REPORTS IN CONNECTION WITH CERTAIN TRANSACTIONS NOT INITIATED BY THE CONSUMER. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to require consumer authorization for credit or insurance transactions not initiated by the consumer. Full disclosure is necessary for the authorization to be effective. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to require consumer authorization for credit or insurance transactions not initiated by the consumer. The authorization must be accompanied by a notice that fully discloses what is being authorized and its potential effects on the consumer, as jointly prescribed by the Federal Trade Commission and the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System. The notice must be prominently displayed on a separate document. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to require consumer authorization for credit or insurance transactions not initiated by the consumer. The notice must be prominently displayed on a separate document. Subsection (e) of section 604 is repealed. SEC. 5 prohibits the sale or transfer of transaction or experience information. The Fair Credit Reporting Act prohibits the sale or transfer of transaction or experience information without the consumer's consent. This includes details of transactions between the consumer and businesses, such as content, brand names, and merchandise involved. Exceptions to the prohibition on selling or transferring transaction information without consumer consent include communication among related persons, court orders, government licensing, real estate transactions, and required information disclosures. Amendments are made to the Fair Credit Reporting Act regarding information required for perfecting a security interest in personal property and information related to consumer transactions. Technical and clerical amendments are also included. Amendments to the Fair Credit Reporting Act include requirements for transaction or experience information.
